pageProps.contentHtml:
Riemann mapping theorem

An analytic Jordan curve is a set of the form

Γ=f({∣z∣=1})\Gamma = f\p{\set{\abs{z} = 1}}Γ=f({∣z∣=1})

where fff is analytic and 1-1 on an annulus {r<∣z∣<1r}\set{r < \abs{z} < \frac{1}{r}}{r<∣z∣<r1​}, 0<r<10 < r < 10<r<1.

Let C∗=C∪{∞}\C^* = \C \cup \set{\infty}C∗=C∪{∞} be the Riemann sphere, let N<∞N < \inftyN<∞, and let Ω⊆C∗\Omega \subseteq \C^*Ω⊆C∗ be a domain for which ∂Ω\partial\Omega∂Ω has NNN connected components, none of which are single points. Prove there is a conformal (i.e., one-to-one analytic) mapping from Ω\OmegaΩ onto a domain bounded by NNN pairwise disjoint analytic Jordan curves.
Solution.

This problem is probably incorrect as stated. Consider this StackExchange post. The boundary of the curve in the question is self-intersecting, so it cannot be the image of any 1-1 function. Instead, the problem should say that C∗∖Ω\C^* \setminus \OmegaC∗∖Ω has NNN connected components, rather than the boundary itself having NNN connected components.

Let NNN be the number of connected components of Ω\OmegaΩ. We will show that Ω\OmegaΩ is conformally equivalent to D∖(E1∪⋯∪EN−1)\D \setminus \p{E_1 \cup \cdots \cup E_{N-1}}D∖(E1​∪⋯∪EN−1​) where E1,…,EN−1⊆DE_1, \ldots, E_{N-1} \subseteq \DE1​,…,EN−1​⊆D are simply connected by induction on NNN:

If N=1N = 1N=1, then Ω\OmegaΩ is simply connected. If this were not the case, then there exists a simple closed curve γ⊆Ω\gamma \subseteq \Omegaγ⊆Ω which is not contractible to a point. Hence, the interior of γ\gammaγ contains a point z0∈C∗∖Ωz_0 \in \C^* \setminus \Omegaz0​∈C∗∖Ω. This means that C∗∖Ω\C^* \setminus \OmegaC∗∖Ω is contained in the interior of γ\gammaγ since it is connected, but this implies that z0z_0z0​ is in a different component of the portion of C∗∖Ω\C^* \setminus \OmegaC∗∖Ω which lies in the exterior of γ\gammaγ, a contradiction. Hence, Ω\OmegaΩ is simply connected with more than one point in its complement, so by the Riemann mapping theorem, Ω\OmegaΩ is conformally equivalent to D\DD. Since ∂D\partial\D∂D is the unit circle, it is trivially an analytic Jordan curve.

Now suppose that the claim is true when for domains with NNN connected components in its complement, and assume C∗∖Ω\C^* \setminus \OmegaC∗∖Ω has N+1N + 1N+1 connected components, C1,…,CN+1C_1, \ldots, C_{N+1}C1​,…,CN+1​. Let Ω′=Ω∪CN+1\Omega' = \Omega \cup C_{N+1}Ω′=Ω∪CN+1​, which has C∗∖Ω′=C1∪⋯∪CN\C^* \setminus \Omega' = C_1 \cup \cdots \cup C_NC∗∖Ω′=C1​∪⋯∪CN​. By the inductive hypothesis, we get a conformal map φ ⁣:Ω′→D∖(E1∪⋯∪EN−1)\func{\phi}{\Omega'}{\D \setminus \p{E_1 \cup \cdots \cup E_{N-1}}}φ:Ω′→D∖(E1​∪⋯∪EN−1​) with the EkE_kEk​'s simply connected. On the other hand, if we let U=C∗∖φ(CN+1)U = \C^* \setminus \phi\p{C_{N+1}}U=C∗∖φ(CN+1​), then C∗∖U\C^* \setminus UC∗∖U has only one connected component, so by the argument above, we see that UUU is simply connected. Thus, because CN+1C_{N+1}CN+1​ is not a singleton, the Riemann mapping theorem gives a conformal map ψ ⁣:U→D\func{\psi}{U}{\D}ψ:U→D.

If EN+1=φ(CN+1)E_{N+1} = \phi\p{C_{N+1}}EN+1​=φ(CN+1​), then we get the conformal map

φ∣Ω ⁣:Ω→D∖(E1∪⋯∪EN+1)\func{\res{\phi}{\Omega}}{\Omega}{\D \setminus \p{E_1 \cup \cdots \cup E_{N+1}}}φ∣Ω​:Ω→D∖(E1​∪⋯∪EN+1​)

with

ψ(∂EN+1)=ψ(∂(C∗∖U))=∂D,\psi\p{\partial E_{N+1}} = \psi\p{\partial\p{\C^* \setminus U}} = \partial\D,ψ(∂EN+1​)=ψ(∂(C∗∖U))=∂D,

i.e., ∂EN+1\partial E_{N+1}∂EN+1​ is conformally equivalent to S1S^1S1, which is an analytic Jordan curve, and this completes the proof.
